Hackville 2020

A cohesive brand for a student-wide hackathon.

Branding

UI Design

Creative Direction

Project Info

Project Type Student Event

Team Galaxia Wu, Wilson Truong, Daniella Sapiente

My Role Design Lead, Branding, UI Design, and Visual Design

Timeline 3 weeks

Tools Adobe XD, Illustrator

Hackville is Sheridan College's student-organized hackathon, that presents challenging problems to incite innovative solutions, insightful workshops, inspiring speakers, direct networking, and mentorship. The competition was open to 100 post-secondary students who love a challenge and who were looking to gain relevant experience.

Overview

Scaling a team of new designers.

This was my first time leading a team of 3 other designers, all coming in with various skill levels. As the Hackademics team continued to scale up, I wanted to produce something with lasting change for the organization to increase efficiency and help maintain consistency across platforms. To uphold Hackville's brand values and visual direction, I created a brand and illustration guide for my team to follow for this and future events.

The Problem

How might we uphold brand consistency using visual language to make our event appealing to students?

Competitive Analysis

When studying other hackathons, I found the quality of their branding to vary significantly due to most organizers being students (many without design backgrounds); many looking outdated. Well-established institutions with long-standing hackathons typically had the highest quality branding. Most opted for the flat or isometric illustration, coloured with tech blues, purples, reds, and whites.

People vector created by macrovector - www.freepik.com

Moodboard

I was inspired by geometric, flat style for its clean lines, replicability, and easily reusable within a component library. I liked the idea of creating a theme around complex systems and machinery for the designs as the challenge theme for the event was smart cities.

The Solution

A comprehensive brand guide and illustration guide.

Deliverables

  • Brand guide
  • Illustration guide
  • Website UI
  • Event Assets
Wordmark
Lettermark

The previous lead had created the wordmark and lettermark here; however, in the brand guide, I added spacing guides for each and rules on applying the marks to various assets. The guide gave newer design team members and team members from the other teams something to refer to ensure the marks were used correctly.

Typography
Colours
#00194B
#2D65B5
#5D92D1
#CDDCF1
#FFFFFF
#141414

Illustration Guide

I added three fundamental illustrative elements for my team to follow within the guide: the shapes, highlights and outlines, and the grid. To maintain the geometric style and elicit a blueprint essence, designers created on top of a grid using seven basic shapes to build out the illustrations. Designers could add highlights or outlines using a single stroke to add detail to the shapes.

Illustration Guide

Illustration Examples

Event Assets

Registration Site

Event banner

Display schedule

Reflection

Ideas are always stronger when backed by a good story.

This project taught me about leadership, managing a team, and setting them up for success. I felt it was vital that I aligned all members on the vision in a way that was communicated clearly and comprehensibly to give the tasks a greater sense of purpose.

If I were to do a project like this again, I think creating brainstorming workshops for the team to inspire collaboration and give everyone a chance to get to know each other better.

I wish I had focused more on the target audience and their needs and goals at the beginning of the project to help me create a stronger story within the creative direction and visual design. At the time, the direction was just a cool idea, but it lacked substance and cohesion. Spending less time obsessing over perfecting the guides and allowing myself and the team to get creating faster would've been a better decision in this case.
